7.36.text:
>>Martha Kearney: As we mentioned, we are
going to move now on to how the Five Year

11.46.text:
Forward View is being implemented, so we will
get the next panel up here, and what impact

16.84.text:
the STPs, the sustainability and transformation
plans, are having in each of the 44, what

22.97.text:
are known as ‘local footprints.’
So, these are the members of the panel that

26.55.text:
we are going to be talking to now. Matthew
Swindells, a National Director Operations

31.84.text:
and Information, NHS England; Amanda Doyle,
Chief Clinical Officer of Blackpool CCG and

37.62.text:
the STP Lead for Lancashire and South Cumbria;
David McNulty, Chief Executive of Surrey County

44.74.text:
Council; and Sir Andrew Morris, who is Chief
Executive of Frimley Park Hospital, which

50.01.text:
is also in Surrey. Now, I wanted to ask a
question, which I am sure many people in the

54.32.text:
room will know the answer to, but some people
might not. If you are not a health geek, what

59.24.text: exactly is an STP and what is its purpose?

66.24.text:
>>Matthew Swindells: Thank you. Shall I pick
that up? Although I think they will all have

68.67.text:
their own views on this.
>>Martha Kearney: Yes, thank you. Yes, do.

70.78.text:
>>Matthew Swindells: So, STPs were created
after the Five Year Forward View was published,

76.52.text:
two years ago now, to say that the challenges
laid out for NHS and social care in the Five

83.88.text:
Year Forward View required a joined-up solution;
it was not something you could solve GP practice

88.83.text:
by GP practice, hospital by hospital, social
care by social care. We needed to think about

93.73.text:
the experience that patients had and the way
in which the whole of the system works together.

99.31.text:
So, STPs were announced about a year ago now,
in the planning round last year, to bring

105.91.text:
together representatives of the health and
social care system in order to address those

112.05.text:
challenges and come up with joined-up solutions
that address the question of: how do we improve

118.48.text:
the experience that patients have, how do
we improve the health of populations and how

122.52.text:
do we get improved efficiency across the NHS?
By working together and coming up with sophisticated

128.68.text:
whole-system solutions to what are complex
problems in the 21st century.

134.16.text:
>>Martha Kearney: Andrew Morris, you are at
the front line of this. However, from a patient’s

142.41.text:
perspective, why is this not just a talking
shop? What are the concrete examples of what

147.20.text:
can be achieved?
>>Andrew Morris: Okay, thank you. Firstly,

150.21.text:
there is an opportunity here to reconfigure
GP services. So, in our STP we want to offer

156.70.text:
access for an urgent appointment seven days
a week, 08.00 until 20.00; that is a major

161.90.text:
step forward. Every day we will have, literally,
several hundred people come to one of our

168.86.text:
two A&Es who really do not need to be there.
If you have access to a GP from 08.00 to 20.00

177.87.text:
for an urgent slot, seven days a week, there
will be less work coming into hospital.

183.29.text:
The second strand to our STP is around developing
integrated hubs. So, can we get the GPs to

192.07.text:
work with a team of community nurses, with
some mental health support, some social work

196.87.text:
support and some consultant support around
looking after the really, really sick and

202.70.text:
frail people who are likely to come into hospital,
and can we wrap a management plan that keeps

209.34.text:
them in their own home for longer? So, if
you look at the last five years of most people’s

217.91.text:
lives, the hospital will always get you, in
the main, but you will end up coming in five

224.72.text:
or six times. What we are trying to do is
to create a different offering, because that

229.59.text:
is quite expensive, and the alternative would
be that we support you in your own home for

235.25.text:
a lot longer, so perhaps you only come in
once, or preferably not at all.

241.64.text:
In our STP we serve 750,000 people. About
half of the expenditure is on acute services,

249.75.text:
and we want to shift that balance; we want
to spend more in community services, and I

254.69.text:
think that will make a big difference to the
way in which people can access services.

259.50.text:
>>Martha Kearney: Amanda Doyle, in your part
of the world in Blackpool – somebody was

263.05.text:
talking about health inequalities – clearly,
that is very acute in your area. What difference

268.24.text:
do you think having these kind of plans is
likely to make?

271.40.text:
>>Amanda Doyle: One of the big challenges
we face in coming up with our plans is managing

279.46.text:
to prevent ill-health and managing to put
measures in place once people already have

285.73.text:
a long-term condition to prevent complications,
so that in the longer term we reduce demand

290.79.text:
on the Health Service. One of the problems
we have got is that the demand on the Health

295.72.text:
Service is rising at such a rate that we cannot
keep up with it if we continue to do things

300.68.text:
the way we do now.
A key focus of our plan is about supporting

305.09.text:
people with long-term conditions to manage
their own condition; giving them the information

311.05.text:
that is required; using technology better
to enable people to understand and look after

317.75.text:
their conditions; to help people with minor
self-limiting conditions look after themselves

323.51.text:
better in a better-informed way at home; to
enable people to be supported in their own

330.18.text:
home in the community by primary care; and
enable us to reduce demand on hospital services.

337.87.text:
You cannot do that without transforming out-of-hospital
services. This will result in a significant

344.35.text:
shift of our investment and resource away
from the hospital sector and into doing things

351.38.text:
in general practice and community services,
through the voluntary sector and use of better

359.63.text:
information and support for patients. All
of which gets more bang for your buck when

363.92.text:
you are talking about health and care services.
>>Martha Kearney: Are you not just picking

367.07.text:
up on what you were saying at the outset,
that there is quite a lot of individual responsibility

371.16.text:
for patients themselves as well?
>>Amanda Doyle: Absolutely. We need a population

377.62.text:
who is empowered and supported to take greater
responsibility for not only keeping themselves

385.27.text:
well, but managing their health and their
long-term conditions. We need to support our

393.25.text:
community and our population in Lancashire
and South Cumbria to take the steps that are

397.68.text:
needed to keep themselves well, rather than
rely on us to treat them when they are ill.

404.05.text:
That means helping people stop smoking, helping
people drink less alcohol, helping people

409.69.text:
exercise more and manage their lifestyle,
so that they reduce their weight and are not

414.27.text:
at risk of long-term conditions. We can support
people to do that, we can give them the information

419.73.text:
and the help they need, but we cannot do it
for them. We need a population who is able

426.59.text:
and feels able and empowered to do that themselves.
>>Martha Kearney: Thank you very much. I would

430.63.text:
like to move on now to David McNulty. You
are Chief Executive of a county council, Surrey

435.08.text:
County Council. I imagine there is quite a
lot of pressure on you. Why are you allocating

441.00.text:
some of your time to look at how the NHS operates
in your area? Why is that important?

446.28.text:
>>David McNulty: I think it is common sense
for us, to be honest. For the health colleagues

452.02.text:
and the care colleagues, these might be patients
or users; for us, they are residents. It is

456.04.text:
the same people. What we are trying to do
is make sure that, within Surrey Heartlands,

462.25.text:
within Surrey as a whole, we get the best
possible outcomes for individual residents,

467.34.text:
for families, for areas.
I think the other point for me is that wellbeing

472.57.text:
and health cannot just be left to the work
of health and care professionals. It is actually

478.58.text:
about mobilising the whole of the community,
the whole of the resources that are available

484.30.text:
within the wider set of public services. What
is the contribution of housing? What is the

489.95.text:
contribution of skills? What is the contribution
of general prosperity in the area? All of

494.76.text:
those are going to have an impact on the health
and wellbeing, and help to take some of the

499.62.text:
pressure off the health and care system. To
me, it is just a fundamental contribution

505.50.text:
we can make.
>>Martha Kearney: This is obviously incredibly

507.77.text:
important to you, is it not? It is all very
well producing your Five Year Forward View,

511.14.text:
but it is like pulling a lever and hoping
that something is going to happen, that lever

515.90.text:
called delivery. It is very important that
this happens in different places around the

521.32.text:
country.
>>Simon Stevens: Yes. I think it is less about

524.16.text:
pulling a lever; it is more about empowering
front‑line leaders, patients and the staff

528.55.text:
of the Health Service and local government
to actually make the changes that they themselves

532.30.text:
can see are needed. Really, it does not matter
what you call it; all this is just a structured

536.33.text:
way for people to figure out what some of
the daft things are that have been going on

539.93.text:
that everybody can see needs to change, and
then actually to agree how to bring those

543.25.text:
changes about. The result of that will hopefully
be some very tangible gains, so that if it

548.91.text:
is your mum, the home help and the district
nurse and the GP service are now all in the

555.92.text:
picture as to what support your mum is getting.
If they repeatedly believe they needs to go

564.58.text:
to the A&E department, because they are not
quite sure what this walk-in centre or this

567.83.text:
urgent care is, or they cannot get a GP appointment;
well, we have actually made it easier to get

572.10.text:
the urgent GP appointment. Then people are
getting their full health needs looked after:

576.36.text:
if it is the person Jane was talking about
earlier with learning disabilities, then they

579.92.text:
are also getting their blood pressure checked
and a dental check-up at the same time. It

584.17.text:
may sound complicated, but when the rubber
hits the road it is this kind of stuff that

588.67.text:
actually will be the test as to whether or
not it is a practical difference.

592.47.text:
>>Martha Kearney: Lovely. I would like to
open this up to the floor now, particularly

595.55.text:
questions about how STPs work. Then we are
going to move to general questions towards

612.28.text:
>>Sue Bailey: Sue Bailey, Chair of the Academy
of Medical Royal Colleges. Thank you for plugging

615.62.text:
Choosing Wisely, I will come back to that.
Thank you for talking about going from an

620.16.text:
illness to a wellness model. I find that a
bit sort of perplexing, as we spend a pittance

625.37.text:
on prevention. My question is: what are the
STPs and NHS England going to do to support

632.33.text:
the lifeblood of the NHS social care and voluntary
sector, the workforce? We have relentlessly

638.17.text:
squeezed out of them their emotional intelligence
and their resilience over the years because

643.85.text:
of austerity, because of pressures, because
of social inequality, because of everything

647.74.text:
that is going on around us. How are we going
to bring that back so they can function, they

653.37.text:
have time to listen to patients and to understand
the fundamental thing that no two human beings,

659.60.text:
including every member of that panel up there,
experience their illness or disability in

664.81.text:
the same way?
>>Martha Kearney: Powerful question, let us

667.45.text:
get some answers to that. Simon Stevens?
>>Simon Stevens: I will kick off, but it may

670.67.text:
be that Jane and Bruce Keogh also want to
chip in, if that is permitted, Martha. I think

675.79.text:
the first thing, Sue, to say is that I think
your description would be well understood

681.58.text:
and accepted across the NHS, and for the 1.3 million
people who are working in the NHS and then

688.28.text:
more than that who are working in the social
care system. I think we have just got to be

692.28.text:
very frank about it: this is a time of great
stress and high pressure. What can we do about

696.67.text:
it? One of the things we have to do about
it is we have got to reduce our reliance on

703.07.text:
temporary staffing and agency staffing, and
have more well-paying permanent posts so that

707.98.text:
people have got stable teams that they are
working with. There is a huge effort on, as

711.50.text:
you know, across the NHS to do that.
Secondly, we have got to be very concerted

716.43.text:
about expanding staff numbers in key areas
where we know we need to do more. In the case

722.35.text:
of, say, child and adolescent mental health
services that Tim was talking about, there

726.64.text:
are about 650 child and adolescent psychiatrists.
We know we are going to need substantially

731.72.text:
more than that if we are going to be able
to look after more than the one in three young

735.78.text:
people who will get the service from the CAMHS
services who need it. We have got a targeted

743.82.text:
increase in a number of these areas.
We also, in fact as the government announced

748.99.text:
a couple of weeks ago, know that we need to
be addressing some very long-standing shortfalls

754.63.text:
in our medical staffing. So, another 1,500
medical graduates are going to have no impact

762.12.text:
today or tomorrow or the day after, but looking
out over ten years or 15 years, it is a vote

768.27.text: of confidence in an expanding and a more comprehensive Health Service.

772.72.text:
Then there is a whole lot of stuff about the
way the NHS itself operates where we can do

777.10.text:
a lot better. One of the things I personally
care a lot about is that we do not do a good

781.45.text:
enough job of looking after the health and
wellbeing of own staff. NHS England became

788.05.text:
the first health service in the world to provide
a full GP health and wellbeing service, which

795.82.text:
comes online this coming January. We have
just commissioned that. I see you are sitting

799.74.text:
next to Maureen Baker from the Royal College
of GPs, who may want to talk a bit about that

804.49.text:
as well. We know that there is a lot more
that individual hospitals and employers could

809.14.text:
be doing around the stress and wellbeing,
musculoskeletal services and other offers

814.85.text:
for staff, and we have created a £450 million
incentive programme for hospitals this year

821.69.text:
to try and help the NHS raise its own game
as a healthy employer.

826.26.text:
>>Martha Kearney: I want to bring Jane Cummings
in, and perhaps to pick up on emotional intelligence

836.72.text:
being squeezed out of the system?
>>Jane Cummings: I think it is a very valid

841.30.text:
point. We know that the services and the people
that provide those services are under extreme

846.90.text:
pressure. I spend a lot of my time with front‑line
nurses, midwives and care staff. I do think

852.65.text:
that some of the things that Simon has talked
about are really important, and perhaps for

855.45.text:
us one of the most important things is about
improving staff experience: helping people

860.91.text:
to feel valued, empowered, able to speak up,
and actually listening to them. When you look

866.04.text:
at the evidence around staff that feel fully
engaged, it does actually help in terms of

871.82.text:
their own wellbeing and their ability to cope
with what are undoubtedly inordinate pressures.

879.13.text:
We are also working about, what are people
doing that is wasting time? One of the most

887.10.text:
frustrating things for clinicians is if they
are doing things that they do not think they

892.09.text:
need to do, that they are doing because they
are filling a gap because there is not a receptionist

896.09.text:
or there is not a porter or there is not somebody
to go and collect drugs from the pharmacy.

901.74.text:
Actually, if you start to look at that and
start to provide support for that, so you

906.81.text:
can free them up to do what they are trained
and well educated to do, that does make a

911.29.text:
big difference. Then thirdly, I would say
this is about looking at the whole team. It

916.25.text:
is not about looking at people in silos and
individual professionals; it is about looking

920.62.text:
at the whole team and working out who is best
placed to deliver the right care for those

924.78.text:
patients. That might mean that there are some
new roles. It might mean that in emergency

930.39.text:
departments we have more physiotherapists,
we will maybe have other clinical professionals

935.13.text:
that can actually support those services.
However, we look at it together and we actually

939.72.text:
ask staff what would make their job better;
alongside, as Simon has pointed out, the need

945.30.text:
in some cases certainly to increase the numbers
of staff we have got.

950.27.text:
>>Martha Kearney: Lovely. Thank you very much.
We have lots more people who would like to

953.99.text:
ask questions. It would be particularly good
if it was STPs.

962.20.text:
>>Maureen Baker: Thank you. Maureen Baker,
Royal College of GPs. My question is to Sir Andrew

966.10.text:
Morris. I am interested in what you said about
GPs providing appointments 08.00 to 20.00,

974.11.text:
seven days a week, and GPs also doing much
more to look after patients in their own home,

982.38.text:
at the same time as we have heard from Simon
about the lack of investment support there

989.07.text:
has been up to now for GPs. I do very much
welcome the announcement about the occupational

995.83.text:
health service for GPs, but I would just as
rather they did not need to use it on account

1000.53.text:
of trying to cope with the intolerable demands.
How is the STP going to support GPs so that

1008.08.text:
the whole system can work for everyone’s
sake, and not just for letting acute hospitals

1016.90.text:
>>Andrew Morris: Thank you. It is a very good
question. If you come to Surrey Heath, that

1021.97.text:
is Camberley and Bagshot, serves about 100,000
people, we have got GPs running a service

1028.75.text:
08.00 till 20.00 for their urgent patients.
We have got GPs in charge of an integrated

1033.69.text:
care team that are monitoring the high-risk
patients that are likely to come into a hospital

1038.98.text:
setting, and keeping them out of hospital
with their teams. That is already happening,

1043.58.text:
and it is happened within existing resources.
We made a conscious decision two years ago

1049.67.text:
that we would have less work coming into the
hospital as an enabler to actually pump‑prime

1057.94.text:
that particular initiative. That is in being
presently.

1062.57.text:
I think general practice is under enormous
pressure, and you have to ask yourself the

1068.25.text:
question: do GPs need to do everything they
are currently doing? Can we get a service

1074.22.text:
that is differently configured? Whilst there
is a massive investment in GPs going forward,

1081.26.text:
I think there is a greater potential around
doing things in a very different way. If you

1086.59.text:
have put your back out, you currently see
a GP. Why do you not see a physio straight

1091.44.text:
away instead? Can nurses do a lot more than
they are currently doing around taking some

1097.67.text:
of the pressure off the GP community?
I also think with hubs, there is an opportunity

1104.53.text:
to bring GPs together and use the scale to
maximum advantage. If you have got a hub that

1112.65.text:
serves 30,000–50,000 people, you can do
things very differently. I think GPs are going

1121.06.text:
to be our front strikers for the future, and
we need to get them resourced really, really

1127.57.text:
well. I have been in the Health Service 40
years now, and I can remember the times in

1134.17.text:
the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s where the growth
in the hospital sector was very minute. We

1140.92.text:
all used to celebrate 3% growth in medical
emergency admissions. It is now 10% or 12%.

1147.83.text:
We need to go back to those days where it
was literally 3% and 4%. The way to do that

1153.73.text:
is to invest in primary care. That has got
to be the way forward.

1157.18.text:
>>Martha Kearney: Thank you very much.
>>Amanda Doyle: I am a GP, as you know Maureen.

1163.93.text:
One of the most frustrating things as a GP
is that you feel as though you cannot always

1169.91.text:
do the best for the patient in front of you
because of the complex way we organise our

1175.54.text:
system in silos, and we pass patients off
from one professional to another or one department

1182.74.text:
to another or one service to another. Every
one of those hand-offs is a gap that patients

1187.59.text:
fall through. That takes a lot of time. It
is complex and it is frustrating, both for

1192.19.text:
the GP and the patients. One of the things
STPs are doing for the first time is planning

1198.24.text:
our system with everybody around the table.
>>Martha Kearney: What would be a concrete

1202.52.text:
example of where you have been able to break
down the barriers of the silos?

1206.71.text:
>>Amanda Doyle: What we are doing is planning
integrated teams where we have agreed what

1211.26.text:
the clinical pathway for a patient is, and
it does not matter who the person in front

1216.18.text:
of them is. They can get the patient on that
pathway whether that is a district nurse or

1220.41.text:
a member of the hospice team or the clinical
pharmacist who has seen the patient in a practice.

1225.95.text:
For patients who perhaps have been discharged
from hospital yesterday and cannot really

1232.51.text:
remember what was said about what was wrong
with them and cannot really remember what

1236.04.text:
they are supposed to do with all these new
tablets, and are not sure what anybody said

1239.83.text:
about how they would be followed up, we can
streamline some of those pathways. The first

1245.29.text:
point of call for that patient does not always
have to be the GP because they do not know

1249.57.text:
who else to call; an integrated team can pick
up and proactively contact that patient. A

1255.61.text:
support worker can contact them the next morning
and say, ‘Do you know what you have got

1259.61.text:
to do? Do you know when your next appointment
is? Have you got the right medication? Do

1263.17.text:
you know what to do with it?’ Those sorts
of things make a tangible difference, not

1266.65.text:
only to patients but to the working lives
of some of our clinicians. While offering

1272.82.text:
ever-increasing access to primary care, we
have to recognise that we do not have enough

1279.64.text:
GPs at the moment so we have to look at the
wider teams we have got, wider range of clinicians

1287.12.text:
and workers who can support our patients outside
of the hospital.

1290.87.text:
>>Martha Kearney: Thank you very much.
>>Tony O’Sullivan: Thanks very much. I also

1299.37.text:
have 40 years’ experience in the Health
Service, and I am now a recently-retired paediatrician

1305.13.text:
spending all my life as a clinician trying
to get joined-up working across the agencies,

1311.80.text:
and successfully too. However, now I am co-chair
of Keep Our NHS Public and what I really worry

1319.17.text:
about is the huge elephant in the room here.
The real reason for the STPs is financially

1328.93.text:
driven; that has been said by other people,
by Chris Hopson and by The King’s Fund.

1334.03.text:
I think Simon Stevens knows that. If we looked
him in the eye, he would tell us.

1338.43.text:
>>Simon Stevens: You are; you are looking
me in the eye.

1340.15.text:
>>Martha Kearney: Okay. You are looking him
in the eye, but bring it to a question.

1342.67.text:
>>Tony O’Sullivan: I certainly do have a
question so just give me a moment, please.

1346.48.text:
I know that public health is being cut, so
smoking cessation programmes have been cut

1354.94.text:
in South East London; not fostered but cut.
Health visiting input to safeguarding children

1362.06.text:
after social care has also been cut. A really
dangerous process is going on. What I want

1371.73.text:
to ask you is: will you publicise the STPs
now? I think it is just disgraceful, really,

1379.03.text:
that it has been such a secretive process.
In South East London, £1 billion of cuts

1385.26.text:
annually by 2020 on top of £242 million
per year in adult social care. We are talking

1394.32.text:
about fantasy. None of the proposals are new.
I have spent my whole life talking about working

1400.32.text:
together better, better communication so that
is my question. Please release the STPs now,

1409.23.text:
apologise for not doing it earlier and please
say you will definitely go back to the government

1413.57.text:
and demand more money.
>>Martha Kearney: Has the process been too

1417.25.text:
secretive?
>>Simon Stevens: I know all of the STPs do

1421.52.text:
need to be published, and they will be published
within a matter of weeks. That will be for

1429.01.text:
our people to decide locally when they have
got plans that they feel they are in a good

1435.57.text:
position to talk with the public and their
local communities about. As it happens, in

1439.73.text:
South East London the proposition there: you
are right, in a way. You say that a lot of

1445.32.text:
the ideas that have been talked about in South
East London are ideas that have been underway

1449.99.text:
for many years. They have. It is 25 years
since I worked in South East London in the

1455.01.text:
NHS, and things we were talking about then,
now we have actually got to get on and do.

1461.05.text:
The GPs, the hospitals, the community health
services, the local authorities in South East

1466.52.text:
London, they are pretty close to, as I understand
it, having a proposition that they then want

1471.76.text:
to publish and say, ‘This is where we are
headed.’

1475.04.text:
What it will not contain is cuts. Actually,
there will be more money being spent in real

1479.87.text:
terms in the NHS in South East London in five
years’ time than now, but that does not

1484.39.text:
mean there are not efficiencies to be made.
As I understand it, part of what they are

1487.86.text:
doing is saying, ‘Here is what some of them
would look like.’ One of them, for example,

1491.46.text:
is they think they could be much more efficient
in the way orthopaedic services are delivered

1494.83.text:
across South East London, in the same way
that is being done in South West London. This

1499.77.text:
is not the art of the impossible; just look
across the boundaries of individual boroughs

1504.73.text:
in London and we can learn some of the best
practice that exists in other parts of the

1508.61.text:
NHS. The South East London NHS does not exist
in isolation from the broader NHS in London,

1515.00.text:
or indeed the rest of the country.
>>Martha Kearney: Matthew Swindells, you have

1517.22.text:
an overview of this. Are you chasing up local

1524.07.text:

1528.17.text:
areas to get good plans developed that they
can then share with local communities, that

1534.01.text:

1539.71.text:
them.
>>Martha Kearney: They will go out to consultation,

1541.64.text:

>>Matthew Swindells: They will certainly need

1543.78.text:
to go out to consultation. There are other
parts which they will need to discuss with

1548.73.text:
their local populations in order to get input

1554.55.text:
I think the key point that both the speaker
made and that Simon made is that the vast

1559.50.text:
majority of what is coming through in these
plans is good, solid common sense that the

1564.33.text:

kicking around. I also worked in South East

1570.47.text:
London a number of years ago, including managing

1575.46.text:
East London. A lot of this stuff is stuff

1582.49.text:
between hospitals, between primary care, between
community services, with social care, with

1586.91.text:
the local voluntary sector and with local
patients, the NHS can do stuff better for

1591.71.text:
people, rather than saying because we have
always done it like this we must always do

1595.63.text:
it like that because otherwise it would be

1682.41.text:

1687.90.text:

1694.07.text:

1695.87.text:

>>Andrew Morris: If you have got a problem

1700.09.text:

1704.94.text:

1711.55.text:

1716.56.text:

1743.60.text:

1748.52.text:
